message.content:
{
    "speeches": [
        {
            "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
            "rewritten_speech": "Right, folks, first off, huge hugs and support for everyone dealing with yesterday's horrid incident in Southport. It's just heartbreaking, and my thoughts are with them all. Now, let's chat housing! Building more homes is our big project because it powers up the economy and lifts everyone's living standards. It also helps us deal with public service challenges. I'm rolling out a bold plan to sort out the housing crisis. We need to get building pronto—no faffing around. Yes, it may ruffle some feathers, but we’ve dodged the issue for too long. 🏡\n\nHere’s the lowdown: 150,000 kids are in temporary homes, there are 1.3 million households waiting on social housing, and younger folks have fewer chances to own homes now compared to the ‘90s. Rents are soaring at 8.6%, and homelessness is at record heights! The old Tory crew knew about this but sat on their hands. They bragged about making 1 million homes but never even hit their yearly goal of 300,000 homes. Worse, housing targets were made voluntary to placate opposition. Result? We’re slipping below 200,000 new homes a year. Shocking, right?\n\nWe’re taking charge! Labour's fixing the mess with mandatory housing targets for local areas. It's not just about how many new homes are needed but ensuring it respects local views. We're also upgrading the method to figure out housing needs so it’s based on up-to-date info, and we’ll factor in where house prices don’t match local incomes. We're bumping targets from 300,000 to 370,000 homes annually. Some won't like it, but fair's fair—everyone has to pitch in.\n\nOn the green belt: Let’s use dodgy, underused land first. Councils might need to review the greenbelt for housing needs, but they must focus on poorly maintained spots, with clear criteria on what to build. If greenbelt is developed, the community gets 50% affordable housing—which includes social rents—plus schools, GP surgeries, transport, and improved green spaces. Previously, things got built in all the wrong places with no local services—No more of that!\n\nFor truly affordable homes, developers need to move at our pace, and we call on councils and housing folks to back a council house revolution. We’ll bring flexibility into the current affordable homes programme, working with Homes England. We’re pushing for the biggest social and affordable housing boost in generations. In short, we need this to happen—now!\n\nMaintaining existing stock is vital too, so we’re tweaking the right to buy. We’re enhancing council flexibilities with the money from Right to Buy to ensure home supply for vulnerable folks.\n\nOur wider growth plan is intertwined with building the homes and infrastructure—such as labs, factories, data centers, clean energy—and leaving the Tory ban on onshore wind behind. We've set rules for solar developments and clearer expectations for renewable energy sites.\n\nUltimately, every local council needs a development plan—currently, only a third do. These plans are key for community input and averting speculative developments. We’re clearing the planning policy mess and striving for universal plan coverage because communities need a voice in development.\n\nWith this transformative agenda, I'll be tracking our progress against a 13-week target personally. We owe it to 1.5 million new homes to get this right! Let’s prove the doubters wrong and turbocharge local growth! 🚀",
        "speakername": "Lindsay Hoyle",
        "rewritten_speech": "Alright, folks, here's Kemi Badenoch up next. Try to keep it around 7-8 minutes if you can, alright?",
        "speakername": "Kemi Badenoch",
        "rewritten_speech": "Cheers, Mr Speaker. Echoing Angela on yesterday’s Southport tragedy—our hearts go out. Well, Angela’s laid out her housing master plan, which raises a load of questions. Today, we won’t solve them all, but answers would be fab before summer break if possible. 😊\n\nLabour’s got the mandate from the election to make these changes, and our role as opposition is to double-check Labour’s sticking to its promises—no smoke and mirrors allowed! Clarity's a must now.\n\nAngela promised new planning frameworks within 100 days but now says it’ll be year-end—what’s up with that shift? Can she confirm the timing of the national planning framework update?\n\nThey’re changing planning rules left, right, and center, but constant changes result in chaos. How’ll Labour avoid the years of uncertainty? These changes need solid grounding, which Angela claims, but there’s unavoidable turbulence when shifting building policies.\n\nThe targets for housing in London seem to be scaled back? Is this happening elsewhere too? Cities like London have the infrastructure for housing expansion, so why the change from a nearly 100,000 home goal to now just 80,000? How’s that helping when inner-city schools are shutting due to low student numbers?\n\nThis grey belt and Right to Buy stuff need clarity. Does Angela plan to restrict right to buy, meaning today’s youth can’t enjoy discounts she had? Also, councillors are worried their green areas might end up sacrificed for urban demands. What will be there to reassure them?\n\nAngela dipped into beauty and quality of housing. It seems Labour's skimping on well-designed 'beautiful' homes that communities crave. Why stress speed over style?\n\nAnd let’s talk dosh; where's the financial analysis? We all saw the fiscal mess addressed this week, so any plan needs money-chat upfront. How can new revenues and expenses align to prevent frustrating public finances more?\n\nThose are just a few questions. Standing here feels like Labour’s swinging at both ends—not addressing deeper housing needs nor constructing legitimate strategies.",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Big thanks for the intro, Lindsay! Hey, Kemi, running the opposition? 😉 Let's get down to brass tacks: the public gave the Tories the boot! Why? They cleared out the coffers and bailed on their housing promises. Now it's clean-up time for Labour.\n\nWe're fixing the mess, starting with thorough consultations on planning policies shaping up today! Affordable housing faced a similar banjax, so we’re working to retrieve funds and apply them effectively with Homes England. Yeah, the old crew couldn't hit targets—London had bizarrely inflated goals they didn’t reach, not even close!\n\nOur new method tunes into real stats, offering stability for local councils. Green belt, beauty, infrastructure—yes, London’s 100k target was fantasy. We’re adjusting for common sense but still asking the Mayor to step up for 80k.\n\nAs for the growing mayhem, councils have had a nightmarish run with developers ducking commitments. Now, we're ensuring community needs align with development.\n\nCommunities need practical plans for housing and infrastructure—no cutting corners. This isn't last-minute dressing up, tightening up the housing stock is crucial, full stop! We'll keep raising living standards and build 1.5 million new homes. End of story! 🚀",
        "speakername": "Clive Betts",
        "rewritten_speech": "Hey, excited about the housing plan? Me too! Quick couple of questions: Council targets, will they be genuine assessments based on local needs and not arbitrary urban boosts? On social housing, work with councils to ensure land profit benefits the community, not just landowners?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Yup, we’re ditching the random city uplift stuff. Decisions will fit real needs and stability for councils. Land value profits ought to help public budgets, not just pocket landowners!",
        "speakername": "Daisy Cooper",
        "rewritten_speech": "Hi there! Yeah, our planning system was a mess under the Tories! Let’s fix this—will councils' existing plans need revisiting with the new calculations? And on social homes, why not adopt the 150,000 homes yearly goal? Will you nail land banking? Also, what about infrastructure needs and planning fees?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "It kinda depends on how far they're in but if plans are underway, a touch-up instead of a reset is likely. We’ll adjust right to buy to stock needs, ramping up flexible affordable housing grants. Infrastructure will see bolstered planning. Engaging locally stops the wild speculative copies and releases grey belt under strict rules—affordable homes, plus nature perks.",
        "speakername": "Rachel Hopkins",
        "rewritten_speech": "Too many of our folks live in dodgy flats made on a whim! Angela, does Labour promise good-quality affordable housing, like liveable council homes for families?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Spot on! Sorting social housing is vital for solving housing woes. We’re pushing developers to meet promises and engaging all levels to get homes in sync with needed infrastructure.",
        "speakername": "Desmond Swayne",
        "rewritten_speech": "So when does my area’s plan line up with the new standards—not too soon, right?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Nope, your local plan's safe till it updates. Plans ensure we meet real needs, not unnecessary builds.",
        "speakername": "Paula Barker",
        "rewritten_speech": "Great job, Angela! We need homes in Liverpool, but we don't want them grabbed by landlords through right to buy. Is your review happening fast?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Absolutely, Paula! We’re on it! The review’s speedy and aiming to balance right to buy, so homes remain in community hands.",
        "speakername": "Paul Holmes",
        "rewritten_speech": "My area's overbuilt—why pile on more when cities aren’t matching housing demands?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "We get it; every area is unique. Our new method means fair housing targets based on true needs. It's go big or go home time; we’re here to help everyone step up with practical solutions.",
        "speakername": "Liz Twist",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, what about holding developers accountable for the promised green and public spaces?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Totally committed! Brownfield is priority and grey belt comes with strict conditions. Developers must deliver promised public perks!",
        "speakername": "Kit Malthouse",
        "rewritten_speech": "Confirmation that folks’ neighbourhood plans aren’t overridden? And what about natural beauty spaces—are they protected?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Neighbourhood plans stand strong. Natural beauty and green spaces keep their safeguard statuses—no changes there!",
        "speakername": "Emily Darlington",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, love the ambition to make new towns like Milton Keynes! Let’s chat about helping Milton Keynes make it happen!",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Exciting stuff, Emily! Milton Keynes is a role model. Let’s keep the magic going with new developments!",
        "speakername": "Richard Foord",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, why is the line about considering farmland for housing gone? We need more local farms!",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Chill, the protection is still in place. Guidance on farmland use, especially prime spots, remains sound and intact.",
        "speakername": "Mark Ferguson",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, ignore those grumpy comments. Let’s work with local leaders to get the right builds for our areas!",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Right there with you! Partnership with local leaders ensures our plans stick to local needs—it’s what our voters want!",
        "speakername": "Mark Francois",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, this plan’s missing local engagement. My area feels like it's being told what to do. Who foots the bill for the massive infrastructure needs?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Hey Mark, national targets exist to guide everyone right. Efforts include working closely with local councils. Infrastructure costs are in the works—we’re on it!",
        "speakername": "Jo White",
        "rewritten_speech": "I've seen section 106 do good, so how can we strengthen it for infrastructure and making sure developments respond to community needs?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Aced it, Jo! Section 106 is vital for infrastructure, like hospitals. We want councils to have decent resources to utilize it well!",
        "speakername": "James Wild",
        "rewritten_speech": "We've got plans for new homes but roads are jammed. Can we fix this so places can grow?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "You've inherited a mess, but we’re pressing for infrastructure alignment. Let’s work together to relieve bottlenecks with concrete plans!",
        "speakername": "Sarah Owen",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, thank you for fast-tracking much-needed affordable homes. Luton North’s issues with rent and eviction cry for immediate intervention!",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "We feel for people stuck in shoddy, pricey rentals! Our council house revolution can’t come fast enough. We’re committed to sorting this pronto!",
        "speakername": "Lee Anderson",
        "rewritten_speech": "Prioritising folks with local links, Brits, and veterans for new council homes?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "You bet! Local links come first. Council homes shouldn't just be for nostalgia—they’re essential and coming back strong!",
        "speakername": "Ben Goldsborough",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, folks in my patch are fed up waiting on infrastructure after houses spring up. How’re we addressing swift and fair delivery?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Totally get it! Our plans will toughen up section 106 negotiations, ensuring infrastructure joins buildings briskly; councils will enforce this. Let's make life good!",
        "speakername": "Wendy Morton",
        "rewritten_speech": "Hey Angela, not against housing, but forced targets wreck my ward’s charm. What about focusing on brownfield first?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Promise; brownfield's prized! Fair housing targets aren't riding over local wishes—they respect area needs. Join forces with your council to plan smart spaces.",
        "speakername": "Rachael Maskell",
        "rewritten_speech": "We’ve got luxury flats but we need basic, affordable homes—fast! How to pivot existing plans to hit those targets?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Urgent indeed, Rachael. It depends on how far ahead your area is in local plans, but we laid plans for affordable and social housing in the consultation. Let’s shuffle projects and focus on needs!",
        "speakername": "Andrew George",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, haven't housing goals been greed-led swaps, not needs-driven? Cornwall's priced sky-high while locals suffer.",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Right on! Our new method keys into genuine needs, merging affordability and current stock. Cornwall deserves better balancing! This house plan aligns with fair housing for all.",
        "speakername": "Helena Dollimore",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, do you see a green, infrastructure-ready boom that covers our housing and even deals with sewerage?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Sure do! Each policy ensures both development and environment go hand-in-hand. Infrastructure, health, and sustainability shouldn't be an afterthought; they’re key!",
        "speakername": "Roger Gale",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, food production's indispensable, and you're removing planning lines that address land needs. What's the response to planning approvals not executed yet?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Don't worry, Roger. We still preserve farmland and focus on disused sections for development, not essential agriculture bits. We'll tackle slow development too—everything connects!",
        "speakername": "Olivia Bailey",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, talk about balancing new homes and local services like GPs. Can affordable housing numbers grow net-positive this Parliament?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "We’re all about balance, Olivia! Crossing our fingers for prompt implementation. Every effort is focused on ramping up social housing numbers pronto!",
        "speakername": "John Hayes",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela! Beauty should be a given for everyone, wealthy or not. Ready to chat with the Office of Place to plan beautiful builds?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Couldn’t agree more on beauty for all! And chat with the Office of Place to make homes pop with style is in order. Count me in!",
        "speakername": "Naushabah Khan",
        "rewritten_speech": "Residents are struggling with housing insecurities. Angela, how will new plans ease homelessness and temp accommodations?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Housing deeply impacts lives; less stress, more security! Solving homelesness requires strong collaboration, smart use of plans, and lifting standards—priority number one!",
        "speakername": "Adrian Ramsay",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela! Homes in Waveney Valley aren’t within reach. Of your 1.5 million, how many are truly affordable? What’s up with empty homes?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "It's tricky to nail down specifics, but half of grey-belt builds should be affordable. Empty homes need action, but tackling new builds is primary.",
        "speakername": "Alistair Strathern",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, the planning talk is thrilling yet my community feels left behind. Can we trust in rules steering away from dicey development patterns?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Absolutely! Setting these guidelines prioritizes commonsense approaches for communities, pushing for improvements instead of old habits. Let’s rewrite how we develop!",
        "speakername": "Ben Obese-Jecty",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, why approve that waste incinerator against local wishes, when even NHS suggests reducing incineration?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Ben, specific cases are weighed judiciously. We'll base decisions on good evidence and thorough consultation. Happy to meet residents for more discussions.",
        "speakername": "Noah Law",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, cracking down on second homes might help unlock housing. What’s the plan?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "There’s loads of legislation rolling out that should help address second homes, but our main mission is setting housing targets. More to come soon!",
        "speakername": "John Whittingdale",
        "rewritten_speech": "Angela, more homes but roads and services strained! How will infrastructure keep pace?",
        "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
        "rewritten_speech": "Sure thing, John! Infrastructure is a cornerstone in planning—needs solidifying. Sections are beefed up, helping plans sync with real needs!"
        },
        {
            "speakername": "Emma Foody",
            "rewritten_speech": "Angela, must make sure new communities mean infrastructure built early and developers held accountable, right?",
            "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
            "rewritten_speech": "Absolutely, Emma! Infrastructure needs to roll out with homes, and section 106 will beef this up. Let’s see developments tick all the boxes!",
            "speakername": "Jim Shannon",
            "rewritten_speech": "Angela, trouble in Northern Ireland where lower earners struggle for mortgages. Can your plans improve affordability nationwide?",
            "speakername": "Angela Rayner",
            "rewritten_speech": "Spot on, Jim! We need jobs paying decent wages, and also introduce mortgage support. These mean affordability married to opportunity nationwide!",
        "rewritten_speech": "So there it is, my friend! 🔄 Rewriting these speeches was about staying relatable, straightforward, and addressing the critical housing challenge in the simplest way everywhere while keeping the heart in the matter. Let’s get Britain building for everyone! 🏡✨"
        }
    ]
}

{"speeches":[{"speakername":"Ruth Jones","rewritten_speech":"Hey folks, I'm proposing we add alpacas to the list of animals we can't export for slaughter. It makes sense to cover them too, right? 🦙"},{"speakername":"Nigel Evans","rewritten_speech":"Okay, alongside that, we're also talking about adding deer 🦌, llamas 🦙, and reindeer 🦌 to the list. And, maybe in the future, even more animals could be added by authorities in England, Scotland, and Wales after a proper discussion. Let's make sure all the necessary livestock is protected!"},{"speakername":"Ruth Jones","rewritten_speech":"I'm speaking for the opposition, and we're all about amping up animal welfare. Labour has always been strong in this area. We've been pushing for changes, while the Conservatives have been dragging their feet on some promises, like tackling puppy farming. We support this Bill, but it's about time we get it sorted.","type":"paragraph"},{"speakername":"Tan Dhesi","rewritten_speech":"Labour's been asking for a ban on live exports forever. So, why's it taking the Government so long, and why did they drop the Kept Animals Bill? 🤔"},{"speakername":"Ruth Jones","rewritten_speech":"Good question! The delay is too long, and that's why our amendments like adding more species are crucial. Export numbers were wild decades ago, and with new additions, we'll be heading in the right direction. Still waiting on the Minister's answers, though.","type":"paragraph"},{"speakername":"Keir Mather","rewritten_speech":"I support Labour's idea of protecting more animals like deer and alpacas from export, but I'm worried about enforcing the rules if our changes go through. Any thoughts on that? 🤷‍♂️"},{"speakername":"Ruth Jones","rewritten_speech":"Thanks, Keir. We can't let loopholes ruin the Bill's intent. We need a solid approach to stop any future issues—that's what our amendments are about. We're making sure the Government doesn't escape responsibilities they have left out in the past.","type":"paragraph"},{"speakername":"Theresa Villiers","rewritten_speech":"This Bill probably won't cover Northern Ireland due to broader trade obligations. Import/export rules aren't simple because of how everything's tangled up in international deals. But hey, at least we're finally ending live animal exports from mainland Great Britain. 🐄✌️"},{"speakername":"Nigel Evans","rewritten_speech":"Hey folks, a quick reminder: I'm not a Deputy Speaker now; I'm chairing this all-inclusive House meeting. Let's focus on the amendments."},{"speakername":"Alex Sobel","rewritten_speech":"Hey everyone, happy to support Labour's push for adding more animals to this export ban. Alpaca farming is on the rise, and we don't need them being exported. Let's stay ahead of changing farming trends to ensure this Bill is ready for the future."},{"speakername":"Mike Penning","rewritten_speech":"Deer usually aren't farmed; they run wild in forests. So they're not really part of this export discussion."},{"speakername":"Alex Sobel","rewritten_speech":"True, but we’re dealing with both wild and farmed deer. Anyway, what matters is this Bill plus our amendments make sure animal welfare sees real improvements and that farming practices don't find loopholes to exploit in the future.","type":"paragraph"},{"speakername":"Natalie Elphicke","rewritten_speech":"I'm all for this Bill banning live animal exports. My area, Dover, dealt with a lot of them and it's great seeing that end. Just concerned about Ireland, though. Even if not covered by the Bill, things might need review to make sure issues don't pop up there."},{"speakername":"Nigel Evans","rewritten_speech":"More people want to talk? Just make sure you focus on the amendments, not the whole Bill debate."},{"speakername":"Sammy Wilson","rewritten_speech":"Hi everyone, there’s a big irony here! Northern Ireland, which deals with the most live exports, isn't covered by this Bill due to previous agreements. So we’re missing what really needs addressing, while debating areas that don't export anymore. Let’s keep it real and focus where it matters. 😅"},{"speakername":"Henry Smith","rewritten_speech":"Northern Ireland should be treated the same as the rest of the UK, especially when it comes to animal welfare. I feel sorry that it wasn't included in the vote."},{"speakername":"Sammy Wilson","rewritten_speech":"Thanks, Henry. It's a real shame this isn't applied across the whole UK. We'll try to ensure it stays on the agenda before missing an opportunity to fix the issue. Let's not give up!"},{"speakername":"Mike Penning","rewritten_speech":"Right, we're giving more species attention, but truth is public opinion's stopped these exports. Sure, concern over ignoring deer and llamas is there, but turning to the WTO issues, let's regulate properly. That's what matters."},{"speakername":"Sammy Wilson","rewritten_speech":"But the situation is serious with places like Dublin to France using sneaky routes. It's about trading regulations—and real well-being of animals facing those journeys!"},{"speakername":"Mark Spencer","rewritten_speech":"Cheers for backing these changes, folks. We’ll cover more livestock for exports bans. But hey, let's avoid going overboard if there's no real proof other animals are being shipped for slaughter or fattening. This Bill’s tight as is. And props for everyone managing things so you all can speak on it. 👏"},{"speakername":"Neil Hudson","rewritten_speech":"There's been a big issue with horses being illegally exported, saying they're for sport but going for slaughter instead. I'm happy this Bill's putting that to an end."},{"speakername":"Mark Spencer","rewritten_speech":"Thanks for calling it out. We're making a firm stand to end illegal trade wherever possible. True, we want to be sure we’re staying focused on the species with real welfare concerns."},{"speakername":"Ruth Jones","rewritten_speech":"Okay, we’re on board with ditching some amendments for now, but we're still pushing a key change. We want room to include any future livestock additions to this ban. We'll keep urging Parliament not to lose sight of strengthening animal welfare.","type":"paragraph"},{"speakername":"Sammy Wilson","rewritten_speech":"It’s disappointing that we can't apply this to Northern Ireland, where it's needed, due to EU interactions. Unionists wanted a fair UK-wide law but it got knocked back. We’ll keep pushing for equal standards.","type":"paragraph"},{"speakername":"Ruth Jones","rewritten_speech":"Labour's backing this Bill, although it took forever. We've led welfare progress before, and we're keen for more steps soon—like banning puppy smuggling! Let's make animal welfare better, quicker. Thanks to everyone who's worked with us on these issues.","type":"paragraph"},{"speakername":"Steven Bonnar","rewritten_speech":"Hey guys, Scotland’s happy to work together on this Bill, but let's remember not to restrict unique local practices. Fair rules keep our farmers thriving. Keep the bar high for animal rights! 🐑🏴"},{"speakername":"Alison Thewliss","rewritten_speech":"Absolutely, Steven. People in Scotland want to see strong animal welfare that's in line with their values and doesn't fall behind due to delays."},{"speakername":"Sammy Wilson","rewritten_speech":"Our frustration is real—part of the UK isn't included. We risk regulatory differences tearing apart our sense of union belonging. Equal animal welfare needs to be a priority. We’ll keep fighting on that front. 🌊"}]}

{
    "speeches": [
        {
            "speakername": "Stella Creasy",
            "rewritten_speech": "Hey folks, the UK Government is set to slap a £40 fee on importing stuff from the EU starting in April. Bet you didn't see that coming, right? Most businesses don't even know this yet, and let's be real, neither do most of our voters. I mean, is the Government even sure about this move? 

Brexit seems to be like a recurring nightmare—just as you think you're getting better, boom, here comes another wave of nausea. Those fancy blue passports and pints of wine aren't exactly making up for the extra paperwork mountain we're facing now. No way am I saying let's go back to the EU, though. Who's got time for detailed treaty talks when this is already a big mess affecting tons of businesses and jobs? 

Today's topic: How's the Government managing our borders, and what does that mean for our food supply? The UK is already importing 46% of its food, which means we're only self-sufficient by 54%. We got our snacks from the EU last year: £10 billion of fruits and veggies, £6 billion of drinks, and the same with meat. Given that 90% of our dairy, beef, eggs, and pork come from the EU, it's no wonder Brexit's already smacking our food prices. Look at what LSE says—Brexit, not Ukraine or the energy mess, is the guilty party driving up prices. 

And now we have these new import controls adding insult to injury. Less transport, complex customs, and smaller supply chains are pushing us to 'survive' on porridge, even if we're 100% self-reliant on oats. 😬 Let's not fool ourselves that other countries will save us. Even with free trade talks with six other countries, they can't match EU's food shipment levels. Plus, if you care about animal welfare, you'd want EU standards over Australia's or New Zealand's. Geography counts! More border red tape means higher prices and shortage warnings—ouch! 

Brexit brought customs chaos 'cause we ditched the EU market, and we’ve been threatening our new customs rules ever since. Businesses are losing it over the controls that keep getting delayed, and taxpayers are picking up the tab. Like, £700 million spent on empty border facilities—is that really worth the chaos it's causing? In 12 days, importing pork, beef, or even frogs' legs, needs a health certificate and vet signature. Think of it as extra import costs. 

The Government talked about a potential £520 million a year cost but now says the health certificates will be only £330 million. That's like me telling my kids they should be thankful I didn't take the bell on their Easter bunny after all! 😂

Beyond health certificates, the Government’s also probing into a charge to cover a border scheme called the 'common user charge,' starting in 100 days. Price suggestions range from £43 or less or more. British businesses need to know if this is even happening—like, pronto!

Remember, the charges apply to each consignment, be it a lamb leg or a truckload of frogs' legs. 65% of incoming lorries carry multi-consignments (groupage), which means costs will go through the roof. Fact is, Brexit's bonfire of regulations is smouldering, choking small businesses.

There’s a way out—aligning vets with Europe, tapping the pan-Euro Mediterranean convention, or using EU hubs holding non-EU products. Get this, checking 30% of imports is what's planned. Come November, safety declarations for all EU imports will be the norm—just perfect for causing a headache!

Northern Ireland's exceptions and 'not for EU' labels spotlight how tech hasn't eliminated trade barriers. Countries like Belgium have said they're done playing mystery games with U.K.'s trade rules.

A scattering of 20+ import measures coming soon means long ques and delivery hurdles—Dover's set to be one giant lorry park. Logistics UK's Nichola Mallon warns of delays, traffic, rising prices, and less choice for us consumers. We get why checks are needed (think African swine flu) but are we alert enough to stop complications before they start?

Major doubts abound among services. 70% of funding to Dover's health inspectors got cut, which hardly inspires confidence. I’d love some answers from the Minister, like: Are lorry checks happening in 12 days? Will there be enough vets for certificates? If not, when will those start? Will ports be working round the clock, and how about those charges—are they set? 

What will businesses need to pay per consignment? And for the tech side, is the 'single trade window' up to scratch? Let's not forget, Northern Ireland negotiates separately too. With UK-EU exports nosediving from 50ish% in 1999–2000 to just 42% in 2022, it's obvious global companies may just choose less challenging markets. 

There's simply too much red tape. So, Minister, will imports be checked soon or delayed yet again?"
        },
        {
            "speakername": "Rebecca Pow",
            "rewritten_speech": "Big thanks to my colleague Stella for bringing up this hot topic. Implementing the first part of this border target operating model is a big step for the UK, and it's taken a lot of effort from the whole Government team. I’m here to lay out what's happening and tackle some of Stella's concerns, but fair warning, she had a loooong list of questions. I’ll try to address ’em all, and if I miss anything, I promise to send some detailed answers in writing too! ✍️ 😊

Now, folks, we don’t have a choice but to introduce biosecurity controls on imports now that we've moved on from the EU’s strict systems. We bear the responsibility of safeguarding our lands from risks like African swine fever, super bad for pigs, and Xylella, which would be devastating to plants. Picture that wipeout! 

Biosecurity isn't just about protecting our backyard, it also defends our exports and global trading relationships. Trade partners want to see robust biosecurity here, and that's where we can add extra controls if needed. Like swine fever? We went a step further back in 2022—proof that we take these things seriously!

The border target operating model strikes a balance between robust controls and minimizing hassle for importers. During its creation, 10,000 folks joined our meetings, we got loads of written responses and feedback from SMEs, food retailers, you name it. All of that’s factored into phase one, kicking off January 31st.

We're running a handy pilot project for shipments from EU and made logistics for groupage (multiple consignments in a single truck) simpler. So Lorries bringing a mix of goods can use a single export health certificate—easy peasy! The main system will fully go live by April 30th, giving businesses ample time to smooth things over.

By 2025, when the UK border strategy reaches its peak, the model will use snazzy tech enhancing trade simplicity. The single trade window, on its way, means filling info only once—talk about convenience!

To be clear, the single trade window's still in development, managed by His Majesty's Revenue and Customs. Our aim? An easier import process, keeping businesses' regulatory responsibilities light but effective for biosecurity.

Our new system cuts through red tape, guides businesses, and creates better checks against disease threats. That includes ditching controls on low-risk goods we can’t make ourselves like citrus and mangos. Don’t even trip over them veggies; we’re always on guard to tweak policies, focusing only on genuine threats. 

Lots of chatter happened around costs. Compared to the 2022 import-model, our revamped method saves about £500 million annually! Some paperwork reduced and less inspections done remotely.

Running tight on time now, but touching back on some specific points from Stella... 🤞"
        },
        {
            "speakername": "Roger Gale",
            "rewritten_speech": "Order, one at a time please! Let's keep things organised, everyone. 😊"
        }
    ]
}

{"speeches":[{"speakername":"Simon Jupp","rewritten_speech":"Hey, what's being done to make sure local councils are clear and open with us?"},{"speakername":"Simon Hoare","rewritten_speech":"We're always working on keeping things open and honest. The rules we’ve got now make sure councils share important stuff like what they’re spending. Plus, the Office for Local Government is gonna make it even better with data about how well local councils are doing – all available on this cool tool called the local authority data explorer."},{"speakername":"Simon Jupp","rewritten_speech":"Being part of the council’s top team should mean being super honest. But sometimes, past criminal records stay hidden. So, what should council leaders do to make sure their team members come clean about their past if it's relevant?"},{"speakername":"Simon Hoare","rewritten_speech":"Good point, mate. When picking these folks, council leaders need to remember there are rules blocking anyone with three-month or longer jail sentences or who's on the sex offenders register. If leaders don’t know about this, the people involved should be upfront and let their bosses know. They’re supposed to fess up when they’re election candidates anyway. The Nolan principles are there to keep things honest. If you’ve got a specific case, drop me a message with the details – happy to help."}]}

{
    "speeches": [
        {
            "speakername": "Alan Brown",
            "rewritten_speech": "Alright folks, I'm pushing for a Bill that would force the Secretary of State to come up with a plan to compensate women born from 6th April 1950 to 5th April 1960 who got hit hard by sudden increases in the state pension age. 🏛️ Now, there's a whole campaign around this—WASPI (Women Against State Pension Inequality). These 3.8 million women were unexpectedly told they'd have to wait four more years, until 66, to retire, messing up their financial planning big time! Some were even in poor health and taken early retirement expecting a pension by 60. 😞

It's been nine long years of chat and brutal stories heard here, but zilch has happened in terms of help. The Government's ignored them, probably hoping they'll disappear, but they haven’t. Unfortunately, 40,000 women are dying each year without any compensation and already, about 240,000 have passed away. And while these women struggle to enjoy retirement amidst the cost of living crisis, research says half can't even cover essential bills, and a quarter struggle with food expenses.

Back in July 2021, the Parliamentary and Health Service Ombudsman said the government messed up big time by not communicating properly. But shocker, we're still fighting in 2023. The Tories, who were once loud supporters, have gone quiet, and Labour’s too. 🤷‍♀️ Even the Labour leader merely said they feel bad for these women, but words aren’t enough.

I'm urging the Labour leader to stand firm, grow a backbone, and promise compensation when in power. Sadly, the current shadow Work and Pensions Secretary hasn’t mentioned a word about WASPI. 😩

The Ombudsman is taking an age to come up with a solution, though it's been nearly three years since acknowledging the screw-up. These delays just add stress to the already hurt women. As elections approach, the excuse remains that nothing can be done till PHSO concludes its work. Even when that happens, the Department for Work and Pensions might still deny wrongdoing, so we might need a push from Parliament.

The goal here is quick, sensible compensation—not vast amounts. A fair deal using level 5 of the Ombudsman’s scale minimum, ideally level 6, is achievable through this Bill. The WASPI women are practical—no one's asking for the pension age to be lowered back to 60. Just don’t forget the government saved £200 billion from raising the pension age to 66. 💵

Simple tax tweaks could fund the compensation easily in a couple of years. For example, ending the non-dom tax status could rake in £3.6 billion annually, and aligning capital gains tax with income tax rates could bring £10-15 billion yearly. Tackling fraud in PPE and covid support could also drum up funds. Yet, no 'VIP lane' for these women—they can’t even get a meeting with ministers.

I've got tons of stories from constituents, like Ann, who got meningitis, retired at 60 without knowing about the pension age change, and ended up enduring six years without work or pension. Or Marie, whose husband got cancer, forcing her to work for seven extra years. 😞

Then there's Lesley, sometimes juggling three jobs to save for the future, now facing a six-year wait for her pension. Many would’ve upped private pensions or NI contributions had they known, and some gave up holidays and more due to this oversight. But remember, these women are smart and capable, yet were ill-informed and now frustrated by the DWP's denials.

Time to make up for past blunders like the miners' strike, Hillsborough cover-up, infected blood scandal, or the sub-postmaster scandal. These women deserve recognition for their unjust treatment in work, pay, and now pension. Big thanks to WASPI campaigners for sticking together. Together, we’ll get some form of compensation, even if it won't erase the hurt entirely.

The Bill’s ordered to be presented with the backing of numerous MPs from various parties, ready to be read again on April 19th (Bill 164). 📜"
        }
    ]
}

{
    "speeches": [
        {
            "speakername": "Grant Shapps",
            "rewritten_speech": "Hey everyone! Wanted to give a quick update on the whole Ukraine situation as we're now approaching the two-year mark since Russia started their full-on invasion. I vividly remember the early morning of 24th February 2022. Got out of bed really early because Russia had just invaded Ukraine and by 6 am, I was off to a Cobra meeting. Back then, as the Transport Secretary, I chatted via Zoom with Oleksandr Kubrakov, my Ukrainian counterpart then. He was standing in a field outside Kyiv, not knowing how long the city could hold due to the Russian army being so close.

Fast forward to now, Ukraine has been pushing back! Russia's losing ground and a ton of resources, including 356,000 troops. (Yikes!) Ukraine has battered about 30% of Russia's Black Sea fleet, and half of the territory Russia tried to nab is back in Ukrainian hands. While Oleksandr leveled up to Deputy Prime Minister focusing on Ukraine's future restoration, Putin got it all wrong thinking he could wrap this up in days.

We in Britain have been right there with Ukraine, leading in global support. Remember our anti-tank missiles (NLAWs and Javelins)? They were sent even before things got really heated. Our impact has been huge: hit Putin hard with 2,700 tanks down, 5,300 armoured vehicles ruined, and loads more. We've sent 4 million rounds of ammunition, and thanks to our donation of 1,800 air defence missiles, Russia hasn't gotten air superiority like they thought.

Oh, and drones! We've sent 4,000 of those, showing how they're changing warfare's future. To keep ahead, the UK defence drone strategy was just launched, backed by £200 million, marking us as Ukraine's biggest drone friend.

Sea efforts? Yeah, we're going strong there too! Storm Shadows and other systems have helped Ukraine in the Black Sea. Trade has resumed stronger than before, with Ukraine exporting lots, including tonnes of agricultural products.

President Zelensky really appreciates what we've been doing. We've sent 400 different types of equipment to Ukraine. True teamwork shows that when Ukraine gets what’s needed, it can totally win!

The Prime Minister recently announced we're putting an extra £2.5 billion into our military support for Ukraine. That’s over £7 billion spent on military aid alone, and £12 billion total, counting humanitarian and economic support too!

Just today, I'm excited to announce another 200 Brimstone anti-tank missiles heading to Ukraine. They've been super effective on the ground.

We've also got an international fund for Ukraine that's pledged over £900 million, shipping out state-of-the-art drones, electronic warfare, and more.

And let's not forget training. We've trained over 60,000 Ukrainians here in the UK, and our training mission's expanding. Even countries like Kosovo, Estonia, and many more are hopping on board to help train Ukrainian troops.

On the sea front, we're teaming up with Norway and other countries in a maritime coalition to boost Ukraine’s naval capabilities, sending mine detection drones, raiding craft, and more Sea King choppers.

I even announced a new drone coalition effort alongside Latvia to scale up providing FPV drones to Ukraine and support drone schools and test range setups. £200 million has already been earmarked for this, making us Ukraine’s go-to for drone gear.

Beyond all this, we’ve initiated a task force to develop a strong defence industrial partnership with Ukraine, looking to back them for years to come. We've already set the groundwork with a new security cooperation agreement for what we hope will be an enduring alliance.

Ukraine's proved they have the will; they just need the tools to finish the job. Russia's still pushing, bombing places like hospitals in Avdiivka, but with 30% of their federal budget now focused on defence... that's a hefty increase.

Putin's banking on us getting tired, but we're not going to let that happen. We’re all standing strong with Ukraine and ensuring they get the support to win this. Big cheers to the UK and freedom-loving nations pulling together on this one. Let’s get Ukraine that victory! 🎉"
        },
        {
            "speakername": "Grant Shapps",
            "rewritten_speech": "Okay, so I have a slightly different take on our UK response regarding deindustrialisation than the right honourable member. It's tough to suddenly boost production levels when we're not on war footing, but we've done quite well. From what I recall – though don't quote me exactly – our production of munitions and missiles is now at eight times what it was pre-war. 👏

We've been conducting rounds of procurement through the international fund for Ukraine, which we set up and which is still getting more contributions. Australia recently threw in $50 million, which is fantastic! 🎉 From the top of my head, there have been about 27 rounds of contract procurements so far.

Not entirely sure about the specific issue mentioned by the right hon. Member, but I'll get back to you with the details. It's great to see we've built a mechanism where other countries lacking our scale of ambition for Ukraine can chip in, and we handle the big procurement moves on their behalf. We’re sticking to this path! 💪"
        }
    ]
}
